item.title: ZSFG expert page transformation
item.dc:creator: Michele Mizejewski
item.description:
There’s another update to the ongoing project to emphasize human-centered service provided by the library. The ZSFG Library page is no longer just a location page — it now highlights the full breadth of services users can expect. ZSFG Library has always been more challenging to represent and promote, because it serves ...

Read moreZSFG expert page transformation

item.title: User Research Results Part 2: Library News
item.dc:creator: Michele Mizejewski
item.description:
News posts and newsletter content enable the library to share current happenings and to highlight and promote services. Our goal is to make these types of information discoverable in multiple places and whenever possible, put them into the path of the people who will find them most useful. Some users ...

Read moreUser Research Results Part 2: Library News

item.title: User Research Results Part 1: Global Search and Site Search
item.dc:creator: Anna VanderJagt
item.description:
Background In June and July 2020, the UX Team interviewed a representative set of users from the UCSF community as part of a larger user research initiative. Testing focused on learning more about users’ mental models and behaviors through common user testing methods. For a summary of findings see User ...

item.title: User Research Results Recap
item.dc:creator: Anna VanderJagt
item.description:
In May, we announced that we would be user-testing the library website to see how easily it facilitates connection to materials, services, and expert help in several different areas. Using common testing methods, we split the research into two phases that took place in June and July. The first phase ...

Read moreUser Research Results Recap

item.title: Unlock! Structure and Accessibility
item.dc:creator: Michele Mizejewski
item.description:
Accessibility can be a confusing topic, but we can start by looking to UCSF standards and expectations to get a sense of where to focus our efforts. If we’re talking about web content, using platforms (e.g. Moodle, WordPress, Zendesk, LibApps, etc.) that are build with accessibility in mind whenever possible really ...

Read moreUnlock! Structure and Accessibility

item.title: 2020 Website Usability Testing
item.dc:creator: Anna VanderJagt
item.description:
In a sense, the website is the largest branch of the UCSF Library. More users interact with the library through our website than through our physical spaces, and this has been especially true during COVID-19 closures. Part of maintaining the quality of the website involves gathering user data and running ...

Read more2020 Website Usability Testing

item.title: Library Website Accessibility
item.dc:creator: Richard Trott
item.description:
Celebrate Global Accessibility Awareness Day by watching a recording of Michele’s portion of our accessibility interest group meeting, which coincidentally took place today. Michele briefly reviewed the current status of accessibility on a few of the Library’s websites and also talked about a few things she’s discovered lately to help ...

Read moreLibrary Website Accessibility

item.title: External Link Behavior Change
item.dc:creator: Richard Trott
item.description:
To improve website usability and accessibility, we’re changing how external links open. The links will no longer open in a new window or tab by default. Right now, links to our own websites open within the same window (and tab), but external links open in a new window (or tab). ...

Read moreExternal Link Behavior Change

item.title: Group Study Room User Research 2019
item.dc:creator: Anna VanderJagt
item.description:
Summary: Survey results indicate users were generally satisfied with group study rooms in the library, but availability, connectivity, and upkeep discourage some from utilizing this service. Areas for opportunity are based on direct feedback and observation and could be used to guide the direction of the group study room service. ...

Read moreGroup Study Room User Research 2019

item.title: Exporting User Data from LibCal
item.dc:creator: Anna VanderJagt
item.description:
Last December, the UX Team surveyed library staff members about Springshare products to gain a better understanding of use and satisfaction with the suite of products. From the survey results, we learned that staff are generally satisfied and mostly use LibCal in their daily work. Since then, we’ve followed up ...
